Half a mind Thoughts on learning and uncertainty

Enhanced memory as a common effect of active learning (new paper)

01 Aug 2016

I have a new paper out in Mind, Brain, and Education, as part of a special issue on education and memory(?), coauthored with Azzu Ruggeri, Todd Gureckis, and Fei Xu. The paper examines whether one reason that active learning improves outcomes relative to passive conditions (like lectures) is that control over learning leads to enhanced memory (in particular, episodic memory for the events experienced during learning).

In many lab-based tasks, having control over learning (in particular, the selection or pacing of information) leads to better memory compared to yoked conditions in which such control is absent (but the same information is presented). Thus this basic dimension of active control (which is just one part of what people typically think of as active learning) seems to be associated with improved memory. In the paper we argue that this can be for a number of different reasons.

A couple of things struck me while researching this paper:

  • some form of episodic memory plays an important role in many theories of learning – but episodic memory is not really a thing in educational research. Unsurprisingly, people are most interested in measures of conceptual learning–like do you remember a particular definition, or how to solve a certain kind of physics problem. Usually not interested in whether you remember the details of the learning experience, like the activities you completed, the example problems you saw, the conversations you had.

  • there’s an interesting gap in research on inquiry-based learning, not clear how episodic memory for the leaning experience supports conceptual learning and retention. In the paper we speculate as to how episodic memory could play a role, but there’s much more research to be done along these lines.

As always, despite our best efforts it’s inevitable that we missed some papers. If you know of something relevant, let me know!
